head.title: Spare the Praise, Help the Child

hedline.hl1: Spare the Praise, Help the Child

abstract.p: Prof Robert F Drake letter, in response to Oct 18 article, backs theory by educators and child psychologists that too much praise by parents to children may hurt self-esteem

block.p: Your Oct. 18 news article about parents and teachers who overpraise children struck a chord with me.

As a college professor recruited to judge junior high school science project finalists in a science fair several years ago, I was dismayed to learn that if I gave the minimum score in every category, a student would still receive an ''honorable mention'' certificate.
Your Oct. 18 news article about parents and teachers who overpraise children struck a chord with me.

As a college professor recruited to judge junior high school science project finalists in a science fair several years ago, I was dismayed to learn that if I gave the minimum score in every category, a student would still receive an ''honorable mention'' certificate.
Among those honored were students whose work demonstrated a lack of understanding of the underlying scientific concepts for their projects.

I was told that the reason for awarding certificates to all participants was to encourage the students. I am pleased to learn that there is now a movement in education to praise the truly praiseworthy.
The writer is assistant professor of chemistry, Ramapo College.
